prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship
Remedies Table—Employment Relationship—Breach of Fiduciary Duty

para.paratext: Damages to Kirkland personally in the amount of $80,647.95 against the defendants jointly and severally;
Damages to 504418 Alberta Ltd. In the amount of $44,403.00 against the defendant's jointly and severally

Individual plaintiff used numbered company to purchase plumbing business from defendant. Defendant entered into two-year employment agreement as condition of sale. Employment agreement included requirement that defendant promote business. Defendant injured knee and could not perform heavy work Plaintiffs had to borrow money to keep business operating. Defendant formed own companies and performed work for plaintiff's customers. Plaintiff's business failed. Plaintiffs brought action for damages resulting from breach of contract and fiduciary duty.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Defendant grossly violated employment agreement and fiduciary duty by competing with plaintiffs. Individual plaintiff was awarded $80,647.95 for investment loss. Numbered company was awarded over $44,000 for lost revenue resulting from defendant's conduct. Defendant breached his fiduciary duty when, in the face of a binding employment contract, he opened up business on his own and did work for long standing Taylor Made customers under his new trade name; billed the customers, did not refer or report this business to his employer, and even hired several plumbers from Taylor Made.
